People are unsettled. Since Halden’s death and the blackout, nothing feels fixed. I spent so long believing BCI kept us safe, even if it hurt people at the edges.
When the system crumbled, I made a choice—leaked protocols to help people self-govern but kept the BCI abuse data hidden. It just felt too explosive, too soon.
Almost overnight, neighborhoods set up their own councils, using the tools I put out there. Some are grateful, but a few can sense what I left out.
Old colleagues split over it—some think I stabilized things, others think I protected the old ways.
In my own building, trust is thin. Some thank me, others watch me like I’m the enemy.
Strangest part is, my BCI score actually went up. System rewards calm, not truth, I guess.
Sometimes I think I betrayed what I believed in, but maybe I just delayed chaos long enough to help people adapt.
I never imagined I’d have to risk everything just so people could solve things for themselves.

After Halden died, everything fractured—blackouts, riots, leaders desperate to contain things.
I read the secret logs myself. None of this was chance. The BCI was always designed to self-destruct if someone tampered too openly.
Even when neighborhoods formed their councils, you could see old BCI prejudices shaping every vote. Abuse records started resurfacing, hidden by the Council but spread underground.
I’m part of the Innovators, or I was—now it just feels like everyone’s in survival mode, factions falling apart.
Some think I could have released everything, but even partial data caused panic. New systems are only half-formed because everyone’s scared of the truth.
My BCI score jumped—rewarded for stability, not honesty. That’s the joke, right? The system’s metrics still haunt us even now that it’s broken.
I keep a file of messages from people—some grateful, some furious, some begging for direction. I’ve never felt lonelier.
